    Complexity metrics for DEMs

    DEM_intro.Rmd
    library(habtools)
library(raster)
#> Loading required package: sp
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:raster':
#> 
#>     intersect, select, union
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(ggplot2)

    In this vignette, we go over the basic steps to calculate standard complexity metrics for digital elevation models (DEMs). In this example, we use a DEM of 8x8m.

    # Load a raster
dem <- horseshoe
res(dem)
#> [1] 0.01 0.01
plot(dem)

    # The resolution is 0.002m

    Let’s say we want complexity metrics for a certain square around xy-coordinates of size 2m.

    dem1 <- crop_dem(horseshoe, -466, 1269, L = 2, plot = TRUE)

    plot(dem1)

    Height range 

    hr(dem1)
#> [1] 0.9709332

    Rugosity 

    # Height variation method
rg(dem1, L0 = 0.1, method = "hvar", parallel = FALSE) # Parallel = TRUE enables parallel processing using multiple cores to speed up the calculations using the height variation method. Only use this if you have a powerful computer with at least four cores. 
#> [1] 1.530437
           
# Area method
rg(dem1, L0 = 0.1, method = "area")
#> [1] 1.439505

    Fractal dimension 

    # Height variation method
fd(dem1, lvec = c(0.125, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2), plot = T, method = "hvar")

    #> [1] 2.240156
# Area method
fd(dem1, lvec = c(0.05, 0.1, 0.25, 0.5), plot = T, method = "area")

    #> [1] 2.243452

    Multiple metrics 

    rdh(dem1, lvec = c(0.0625, 0.125, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2), method = "hvar")
#>         R        D         H
#> 1 1.42748 2.072211 0.9709332
rdh(dem1, lvec =  c(0.05, 0.1, 0.25, 0.5), method = "area")
#>          R        D         H
#> 1 1.696857 2.243452 0.9709332

    Multiple squares

    The function split_dem() allows you to subdivide a DEM into equal parts. Let’s divide the square into 2x2m squares.

    dem_list <- split_dem(dem, size = 2)
# calculate one metric for all squares
sapply(dem_list, hr)
#>  [1] 0.5162930 0.6127143 0.8358884 0.8814073 0.6774140 0.9377822 0.9958876
#>  [8] 0.9770845 1.1133886 1.0766171 1.1218033 1.0029795 0.9865971 1.1646364
#> [15] 0.9986641 1.3692834

# calculate multiple metrics
data_rdh <- lapply(dem_list, rdh,  method = "hvar", lvec = c(0.0625, 0.125, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2)) %>%
  bind_rows()
    ggplot(data_rdh) +
  geom_point(aes(x = R, y = H, color = D, size = D)) +
  theme_classic()

    Rules of thumb

    • all res have to be same across dems
    • smallest lvec hvar method at least 10x res
    • extent (heighest of lvec) 1 or 2 orders of magnitudes compared to smallest lvec (TEST THIS!) (or scales of interest)
    • lvec needs to be the same across all calculations to make comparisons
